notable_quotes.french: par la mort dieu qu'il s'en repentiroit, et s'en donneroit de garde

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Lamourou to Vincent Henry
notable_quotes.french: par la mort dieu (comme il en est coustumier) qu'il s'en repentiroit, que devant qu'il soit nuict qu'il luy arriveroit de l'ouvrage
notable_quotes.english: by death of God (as is his custom) that he would regret it, that before night work would come to him
notable_quotes.context: Threat during quarrel over meadow rights

notable_quotes.speaker: Vincent Henry to Mengin Lamourou
notable_quotes.french: qu'es que tu fais sorcier, au milieu de mes vaches, en veux tu faire mourir, ne te contente tu pas de ceste cy que tu m'as pense faire noyer
notable_quotes.english: what are you doing sorcerer, in the middle of my cows, do you want to kill them, aren't you satisfied with this one that you nearly made me drown
notable_quotes.context: Vincent Henry publicly calling accused a sorcerer after cow fell in water

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Lamourou to Vincent Henry
notable_quotes.french: es tu bien beste de les tant chercher, le diable les en a porté
notable_quotes.english: you are quite a beast to search for them so much, the devil has carried them off
notable_quotes.context: Mocking Vincent when he was looking for lost animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Vincent Henry to Mengin Lamourou
notable_quotes.french: tu es un vray genot, tu me les a tant menassé que je te mescroy ou ton maitre me les avoir faict perdre
notable_quotes.english: you are a true scoundrel, you have threatened them so much that I suspect you or your master made me lose them
notable_quotes.context: Vincent's response accusing Mengin or his devil master of causing animal losses

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Lamourou to Vincent Henry
notable_quotes.french: Grand Vincent tu te plains quand tu en as quelque une des malades, mais sy tu vien entre la St Remy et St Martin tu veras qu'il en mourra bien et les plus belle tousjours devant, et qu'elles mourront incontinent qu'elles seront malades sans s'en donner de garde
notable_quotes.english: Big Vincent you complain when you have some sick ones, but if you come between St Remy and St Martin you will see that many will die and the most beautiful always first, and they will die immediately upon becoming sick without warning
notable_quotes.context: Ominous prediction about deaths of Vincent's cows, which later came true

notable_quotes.speaker: Vincent Henry to Mengin Lamourou
notable_quotes.french: Oncle Mengin sy vous estiez bien sage, vous ne parlierez de telle affaire, car il ny a personne qui le sache synon Dieu
notable_quotes.english: Uncle Mengin if you were very wise, you would not speak of such matters, for there is no one who knows it except God
notable_quotes.context: Vincent's warning to Mengin about making such predictions

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Lamourou about curé's cow
notable_quotes.french: he Chair Dieu, je l'en ay bien demandé une, et il ne m'en a point voulu laisser
notable_quotes.english: by flesh of God, I asked him for one, and he did not want to let me have it
notable_quotes.context: Angry remark about not being given a cow, which later died

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Lamourou to judges
notable_quotes.french: qu'il voyoit bien qu'il n'en scauroit eschapper
notable_quotes.english: that he saw well that he could not escape from it
notable_quotes.context: Statement before voluntary confession on January 5, 1604

economic_context.details: Accused was dismissed from salines for swearing. Multiple disputes over payment: son's reduced wages (3 gros deducted for lost 6 gros knife), wife's fee for calf delivery (6 gros requested, refused as too much), meadow usage rights. Accused was clearly poor - stated 'pauvre, mais homme de bien' and was too poor to pursue legal action against those who called him witch. Confession mentions he owed money for grain bought on credit and devil promised gold and silver to pay debts.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly rich trial record with extensive witness testimony documenting a pattern of threats followed by animal deaths. The accused was a herdsman whose occupation gave him access to many animals that subsequently died or became ill. Notable features: (1) Clear pattern of quarrel-threat-harm sequence documented by multiple witnesses; (2) Accused's habitual swearing 'par la mort dieu' noted by multiple witnesses; (3) Voluntary confession before torture, but torture still applied; (4) Economic desperation prominent - poverty, debts, disputes over small sums; (5) Confession narrative fits standard template, with transcriber's note that 'record sounds suspiciously as if answers were suggested to him'; (6) Accused named three accomplices at sabbat; (7) Prior accusation by Ydatte Vaultrin who claimed to see him at sabbat; (8) Detailed predictions by accused about animal deaths that reportedly came true; (9) All harms are to animals (no human deaths), primarily cattle; (10) Prosecutor was Rémy (likely Nicolas Rémy, famous witch-hunter and author of Daemonolatreiae).
